articles.headline: Some Signs of an Upturn for the Dollar
articles.snippet: After six years of stumbling against the euro, the dollar may be showing signs of getting back on its feet.
articles.abstract: After six years of stumbling against the euro, the dollar may be showing signs of getting back on its feet.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  After six years of stumbling against the euro, the dollar may be showing signs of getting back on its feet.

articles.headline: Executions Resume, as Do Questions of Fairness
articles.snippet: The release of inmates raises questions about whether states are supplying defendants with adequate counsel.
articles.abstract: The release of inmates raises questions about whether states are supplying defendants with adequate counsel.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C.  The release of the third death row inmate in six months in North Carolina last week is raising fresh questions about whether states are supplying capital-murder defendants with adequate counsel, even as an execution on Tuesday night in Georgia ended a seven-month national suspension.

articles.headline: Clinton’s Options Seem to Dwindle
articles.snippet: She was unable to build her base of support much beyond the white, working-class voters who have sustained her.
articles.abstract: She was unable to build her base of support much beyond the white, working-class voters who have sustained her.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this case, a split was not a draw.

articles.headline: Gas Prices Expected to Peak in June
articles.snippet: As oil futures rose above $122 a barrel, the Energy Department said it expected gasoline prices to peak at a national average of $3.73 a gallon in June.
articles.abstract: As oil futures rose above $122 a barrel, the Energy Department said it expected gasoline prices to peak at a national average of $3.73 a gallon in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: Oil jumped to another record on Tuesday, and the government said it expected gasoline prices to peak at a national average of $3.73 a gallon in June, just as the summer driving season kicks off.

articles.headline: Obama Wins North Carolina Decisively; Clinton Takes Indiana by Slim Margin
articles.snippet: Senator Barack Obama received new ammunition as he sought to persuade Democratic leaders to coalesce around him.
articles.abstract: Senator Barack Obama received new ammunition as he sought to persuade Democratic leaders to coalesce around him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama won a commanding victory in the North Carolina primary on Tuesday and lost narrowly to Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton in Indiana, an outcome that injected a boost of momentum to Mr. Obama’s candidacy as the Democratic nominating contest entered its final month.

articles.headline: After 60 Years, Arabs in Israel Are Outsiders
articles.snippet: Israel’s 1.3 million Arab citizens are still far less well off than Israeli Jews and feel increasingly unwanted.
articles.abstract: Israel’s 1.3 million Arab citizens are still far less well off than Israeli Jews and feel increasingly unwanted.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  As Israel toasts its 60th anniversary in the coming weeks, rejoicing in Jewish national rebirth and democratic values, the Arabs who make up 20 percent of its citizens will not be celebrating. Better off and better integrated than ever in their history, freer than a vast majority of other Arabs, Israel’s 1.3 million Arab citizens are still far less well off than Israeli Jews and feel increasingly unwanted.

articles.headline: Fannie Mae Wins Cheers Despite Loss
articles.snippet: Despite its $2.2 billion quarterly loss, investors were optimistic that the nation’s largest buyer of home loans was in a strong position to select the safest loans available.
articles.abstract: Despite its $2.2 billion quarterly loss, investors were optimistic that the nation’s largest buyer of home loans was in a strong position to select the safest loans available.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fannie Mae, the nation’s largest buyer of home loans, gave investors little reason to cheer Tuesday, announcing a $2.2 billion quarterly loss and a dividend cut, and warning of steeper losses ahead.

articles.headline: Quarrel Erupts Between Bear’s Elder Statesmen
articles.snippet: The collapse of the troubled Wall Street bank has sparked finger-pointing and recrimination by its elder statesmen, Alan C. Greenberg and James E. Cayne.
articles.abstract: The collapse of the troubled Wall Street bank has sparked finger-pointing and recrimination by its elder statesmen, Alan C. Greenberg and James E. Cayne.
articles.lead_paragraph: After 59 years, Alan C. Greenberg is still trading away at Bear Stearns, the troubled Wall Street bank that is about to disappear. Ask about his retirement plans, and he lets out a belly-jiggling laugh.

articles.headline: Seeing Inflation Only in the Prices That Go Up
articles.snippet: Inflation really has gotten worse recently — it was only 2 percent a year and a half ago — but it’s not as bad as it feels.
articles.abstract: Inflation really has gotten worse recently — it was only 2 percent a year and a half ago — but it’s not as bad as it feels.
articles.lead_paragraph: Next week, the Bureau of Labor Statistics will release its monthly report on inflation, and it sure is going to sound strange. Wall Street is expecting the bureau to announce that the Consumer Price Index rose just three-tenths of a percentage point in April. Over the last year, the index has risen only about 4 percent.

articles.headline: Aid for Myanmar Mobilizes, Mixed With Criticism
articles.snippet: An international relief operation was mobilized as the government raised its estimate of the death toll to 22,500 and reported 41,000 still missing.
articles.abstract: An international relief operation was mobilized as the government raised its estimate of the death toll to 22,500 and reported 41,000 still missing.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGKOK  A powerful cyclone that destroyed a vast swath of coastal Myanmar and left many thousands of people dead prompted the country’s military leaders to allow some foreign aid groups to deliver relief supplies on Tuesday. But the ruling junta came under increasing pressure to further open its doors  and even relax its tight political grip  to grapple with the growing disaster.
articles.byline: By Seth Mydans and Helene Cooper
